awd_titl_txt: Excellence in Research: Reconfigurable Supply Chain Network Design and Assembly Planning for Factory-in-a-Box Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
This Excellence in Research (EiR) award will contribute to the advancement of national prosperity and economic welfare by studying efficient operations of mobile manufacturing facilities.  Mobile manufacturing is an emerging paradigm that allows for production modules to be transported by vehicles to demand locations, thus reducing both the cost and time of delivery.  This paradigm has been suggested for diverse, specialized applications, including vaccine manufacturing to respond to spatial disease outbreaks and battlefield or ship-board spare parts manufacturing to repair damaged equipment.  This project addresses a critical enabling aspect of mobile manufacturing, namely how to effectively configure the supporting supply chain and assembly process.  In this new paradigm, suppliers will need to deliver to different manufacturing locations at different times, which may necessitate engaging different suppliers depending on the mobile manufacturing transport sequence. 

This research will build a decision-making framework for supply chain network design and assembly planning explicitly incorporating the logistics of materials delivery.  The PI will employ optimization methods to study two subproblems.  The first will consider a Machine Scheduling Problem to schedule raw material delivery to subassemblies at different suppliers.  The second will consider a Vehicle Routing Problem for the assignment of trucks for transport of the subassemblies from suppliers to the mobile manufacturer.  The PIs will investigate new computational approaches to these difficult optimization problems.  A test platform for production of biological therapeutics using microfluidic devices will allow undergraduate and graduate students the opportunity to develop a working hardware and software mobile "factory-in-a-box".  The project will involve development of educational programs in advanced analytics for engineering systems at the local institution and will provide advanced education and training for minority graduate students as well as summer research for undergraduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on developing a research and education program at Florida A&M University (FAMU), a historically black college/university (HBCU), to address key challenges in quality control and supply chain design optimization for "factory-in-a-box" manufacturing. These innovative manufacturing scheme leverage modular factory units that can be transported to customer locations for on-site production. The project also explored advanced analytics and small-sample machine learning methods to improve quality control in flexible and modular manufacturing environments.

The educational component of the project aimed to inspire and train a diverse group of engineering students, particularly at this HBCU. By focusing on data analytics, optimization, and simulation techniques, the program sought to equip students with the skills necessary for success in analytics-intensive fields and encourage them to pursue graduate-level education.

The project delivered outcomes in both research and education, summarized as follows:

Research Merit

1. Optimization Models and Algorithms
The project developed comprehensive optimization models to address the multi-level decision-making processes inherent in factory-in-a-box manufacturing. These models account for process planning and supply chain configuration/ reconfiguration, enabling manufacturers to rapidly adapt to changing demands and constraints.

A key innovation was the introduction of a graph-based similarity model to estimate supply chain reconfigurability without relying on detailed cost data. This approach addresses a major limitation in existing research, where the lack of granular cost information often hampers the ability to optimize supply chain designs effectively.

To solve the resulting highly nonlinear optimization problems, the team developed robust solution algorithms capable of maintaining computational feasibility. These algorithms provide decision-makers with quantitative tools to optimize modular manufacturing systems in response to emergencies.

2. Use Case Applications
The research yielded practical guidelines for:

  • Supply chain configuration for emerging factory-in-a-box: Developing configurations for factory-in-a-box systems to improve operational efficiency and adaptability.
  • Manufacturing for emergencies: Repurposing supply chains to produce new, high-demand products during emergencies, such as personal protective equipment (PPE) or medical supplies during a pandemic.
  • Mobile Clinics: Designing supply chains for hospitals on wheels, incorporating demand uncertainty and ensuring timely delivery of medical services to underserved regions.

3. Publications and Dissemination

Findings were disseminated widely through (1) 14 papers in high-impact journals with American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME), Institute of Industrial and Systems Engineers (IISE), and Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE), and (2) multiple presentations at IISE and the Institute of Operations Research and Management Sciences (INFORMS). 

Education

1. Ph.D. Student Support
This project supported the research activities of three Ph.D. students, who directly incorporated project topics into their dissertations. All these students successfully graduated by the end of 2024. In addition, two more Ph.D. students were partially supported for their invovlement in data cleaning and assisting REU mentorship.

2. Undergraduate Engagement

The project provided research opportunities for seven undergraduate students through REU program. Students explored topics such as supply chain optimization and small-sample quality control using data science and machine learning techniques. Among these REUs, one African American female developed her honor thesis on scheduling optimization and later transitioned successfully to the Ph.D. program in Industrial Engineering at FAMU. Another African American female student is retained in the Master's graduate program.

3. Student Achievements
Students involved in the project received numerous recognitions, including:

  • A best paper finalist award at the annual conference for industrial engineering.
  • A best poster award at the FAMU graduate student competition, sponsored by industry partners.
  • Travel grants to attend the INFORMS conference, supported by Amazon.
  • Students' industry scholarships sponsored by Danfoss 

4. Curriculum Development
Research findings were integrated into new graduate-level course modules in machine learning and transportation sciences at the Florida A&M University - Florida State University College of Engineering. These modules equip students with new knowledge and skills on small-sample machine learning, simulaiton, and nonlinear optimization.

Summary of Broader Impacts

1. Manufacturing Innovations for Broader Applications
The factory-in-a-box concept extends beyond manufacturing to address critical societal challenges. For example, the project's findings have inspired disaster preparedness and recovery initiatives, leveraging the mobile manufacturing framework to create "service-on-wheels" solutions. These systems could deliver essential services, such as medical care and emergency supplies, to communities impacted by disasters.

Stakeholders in disaster relief at Florida State University has recognized the value of this approach, awarding a $50K seed grant to generalize the concept for disaster response. This funding supports ongoing research to adapt factory-in-a-box methodology innovations to emergency response scenarios.

2. Strengthening Diversity in Analytics-Intensive Major
This project provides educational opportunities and mentorship to underrepresented students in industrial engineering and transportation research. These areas involve extensive math formulations and algorithm development, and much fewer domestic minority students are seen in these fields. This grant has significantly enhanced the diversity in these majors.

3. Industry Collaboration and Impact
This project contributes to the collaborations with industry partners, including Mayo Clinic and Danfoss Turbocore. These collaborative activities highlight the project's relevance to real-world challenges.


Last Modified: 12/09/2024
Modified by: Hui Wang

  • This figure illustrates the supply chain configuration as the factory-in-a-box (FiB) travels from (a) to a new destination (b). The icon showing the factory over the wheels is the FiB, the rectangles represent the manufacturers producing semi-completed modules, and circles are raw material supplier
